newsitem.title: ITALY: Mediaset hails EU court ruling on TV ads.
newsitem.headline: Mediaset hails EU court ruling on TV ads.

text.p: Broadcasting group Mediaset SpA on Thursday welcomed a European Court of Justice ruling on raising limits for broadcast advertising, and said it hoped Italian legislators reforming Italy's broadcasting sector would accept the judgment.

The ruling, announced earlier, addressed a complaint by Broadcaster RTI about Italian limits on the amount of time advertisements can be aired. RTI, owned by Mediaset and other broadcasters, had asked the European court to interpret the EU's "Television without Frontiers" directive.
The court directive says advertising airtime can be increased from 15 percent to 20 percent of total broadcast transmission time.

Mediaset, part of former prime minister Silvio Berlusconi's Fininvest media empire, said in a statement it hoped Italian legislators would accept the judgment and not put Italian broadcasters at a disadvantage to their European competitors.
The broadcasters asked the court to rule on whether the increased limits on advertising air time included telepromotions, saying Italian law unfairly lumped those with spot advertising.
The court ruled the law included telepromotions but said Italian authorities were free to set stricter guidelines as long as they complied with EU rules on freedom of movement.

"Mediaset hopes now Italian lawmakers engaged in reforming the radio-television system take on board the court ruling and that therefore Italian regulations do not place all the commercial TV operators in the country at a disadvantage in respect to their European competitors," it said.
